questions.question_text: Which two methods can be used to add an Oracle 11g database to a multitenant container database (CDB) as a pluggable database (PDB)? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Use the CREATE DATABASE ... ENABLE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement to create a PDB by copying data files from PDB$SEED and use data pump to load data from the Oracle 11g database into the newly created PDB.
choices.E: Upgrade the Oracle 11g database to a 12c non-CDB and use the DBMS_PDB.DESCRIBE procedure to plug the database as a new PDB into the CDB.
choices.A: Use the DBMS_PDB package to plug the Oracle 11g database into the existing CDB as a PDB.
choices.D: Pre-create a PDB in CDB and use the NETWORK_LINK and PARALLEL parameters with data pump import to import data from the Oracle 11g database to the newly created PDB.
choices.C: Pre-create a PDB in CDB and use data pump to load data from the complete database export of the Oracle 11g database into the newly created PDB.

choices.E: an RMAN full backup taken for a database in NOARCHIVELOG mode
choices.A: an RMAN backup taken for an open database in ARCHIVELOG mode
choices.C: a backup taken immediately after a SHUTDOWN ABORT command
choices.D: a user-managed backup taken for a closed database in NOARCHIVELOG mode

questions.question_text: Which two result in an inconsistent backup? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: AC , A backup made when the database is open is inconsistent, as is a backup made after an instance failure or SHUTDOWN ABORT command.

I think A,C

Ans : A
If the database runs in ARCHIVELOG mode, and you back up the archived redo logs and data files, inconsistent backups can be the foundation for a sound backup and recovery strategy. Inconsistent backups offer superior availability because you do not have to shut down the database to make backups that fully protect the database.

Ans: C
Any database backup that is not consistent is an inconsistent backup. A backup made when the database is open is inconsistent, as is a backup made after an instance failure or SHUTDOWN ABORT command. When a database is restored from an inconsistent backup, Oracle Database must perform media recovery before the database can be opened, applying changes from the redo logs that took place after the backup was created.

About Inconsistent RMAN Backups
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/BRADV/rcmcncpt.htm#BRADV99964

the answers provided here seems wrong. if you will based it on the concept of COnsitent and inconsistent backup, answer should be A B

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMQS/GUID-74B864F7-2413-4142-BDB0-7B98BE960462.htm#ADMQS09111

comments.content: Sorry I understood the question vice versa..

discussion.content:
ADF
You can use the CONFIGURE ... BACKUP COPIES command to specify how many copies of each backup piece should be created on the specified device type for the specified type of file. This type of backup is known as a duplexed backup set. The CONFIGURE settings for duplexing only affect backups of data files, control files, and archived logs into backup sets, and do not affect image copies.

questions.question_text: Which three RMAN persistent settings can be set explicitly? (Choose three.)

One of the four database suffered an instance failure.
At the next startup, from which point in the redo logs does instance recovery begin?

choices.E: from a point corresponding to the most recent log switch checkpoint
choices.D: from a point corresponding to the most recent checkpoint of any kind
choices.B: from a point corresponding to the most recent log instance checkpoint
choices.A: from a point corresponding to the most recent successful transaction commit
choices.C: from a point corresponding to the most recent incremental checkpoint

discussion.content:
I think D.
Restore from most recent completed checkpoint.
Regardless of any type of checkpoint.

choices.F: Bring both tablespaces ONLINE and rebuild all the instances in the IDX tablespace.
choices.E: Restore both tablespaces from the most recent backup.

questions.question_text:
One of your databases is in ARCHIVELOG mode and take nightly RMAN backups.
The USERS and IDX tablespaces are missing due to storage array errors.
Which four actions would recover the tablespaces and their contents while the database remains open? (Choose four.)
